Description: Mould-made pottery plastic oil-lamp in the form of a bull's head, with a filling-hole in the centre of the forehead. Between the horns there was a handle(?). The oval nozzle projects from the bull's muzzle, the rim is lost. Covered with a grey slip, reduced Nile silt fabric.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
Parallel from Egypt dated 1st century BC (Bailey 1975, 278, Q607, British Museum GR1963,0715.2). Bailey sites a grey-ware parallel from Alexandria (Bailey 1975, 278).
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (KD.065) (Phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.4603 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
